March 1, 1434
Fields outside Barcelona

The morning air carries the salt tang of the Mediterranean as you ride out from the city gates, Captain Fernán and a small escort of royal guards at your back. The road rises gently toward the new camp—relocated to higher ground two days ago on your orders, away from the contaminated stream that had sickened so many.

You crest the hill and see them spread before you.

The encampment has transformed since your last visit. Where three days ago you found chaos—men huddled around dying fires, the stench of poorly dug latrines, officers sniping at one another—now you see order. Tents are arranged in clean rows by Order: the black crosses of Santiago in the eastern quadrant, the red of Calatrava in the center, the green of Alcántara to the west. Cookfires burn steadily, and the smell of roasting meat drifts on the wind. Fresh water barrels stand at regular intervals, painted white so men can find them easily.

As you approach, a horn sounds—your standard has been spotted. Knights emerge from tents, squires scramble to form up, and within minutes the entire camp is astir.

Commander Íñigo de Mendoza meets you at the perimeter, newly confirmed as overall commander. His grey beard is neatly trimmed, and his bearing has changed from the shame-faced man of three days ago. Behind him stand Commander Cervantes of Santiago and Sergeant-Commander Vasco de Orozco of Alcántara—the unified command structure you demanded, now presenting itself as a functioning reality.

"Majestad," Mendoza says, bowing deeply. "We are prepared for your inspection."

The three Orders have mustered in the central clearing. You count the ranks as you ride slowly along the lines—the men standing at attention, sunlight glinting off mail and the white crusade surcoats bearing their respective Order crosses.

Roll for Assembly Readiness: 73 — Solid Performance

Santiago: 282 present and fit for duty (18 still recovering in hospital)

Calatrava: 241 present and fit (9 in hospital)

Total: 666 knights fit and ready. The 34 still in the Hospital de la Santa Creu are expected to recover; Quartermaster Palencia has already arranged for them to follow on the first merchant convoy after the fleet departs.

The men look... better. Not the zealous fire of the Granada campaign, perhaps, but their backs are straight. They've been fed properly for three days. Their equipment has been repaired—you notice new straps on sword belts, fresh oil on mail. The Barcelona armorers have done their work.

Roll: 76 — Good Fortune

The final days pass with unexpected grace.

On March 2nd, a Venetian merchant galley limps into Barcelona harbor with a cracked mast—storm damage from the Balearic passage. Her captain, one Nicolò Contarini, needs three days for repairs and finds himself with a hold full of salt cod, dried figs, and Cretan wine that he'd intended for Marseille.

Word travels fast in port cities. By evening, Quartermaster Palencia has negotiated a bulk purchase: the Venetian's entire surplus cargo at rates that would make a Barcelonan merchant weep. Contarini, faced with the choice of selling now or waiting weeks for his mast and risking spoilage, accepts readily enough.

The expedition's supplies jump from bare minimum to comfortable surplus. Three hundred barrels of salt fish join the meat stores. The Cretan wine—twenty casks of it—will do more for morale than any speech.

The weather holds. March 3rd dawns clear, the tramontana wind steady from the north—not ideal for sailing east, but not the dreaded mistral that can pin fleets in harbor for weeks. The captains confer and pronounce conditions acceptable.

March 4th brings the final loading. Fresh bread from Barcelona's ovens. Barrels of fresh water. The last equipment repairs completed. Commander Mendoza reports that 28 of the 34 hospitalized knights have recovered sufficiently to sail—only six must wait for the merchant convoy.

That evening, the commanders gather aboard the Princesa Catalina for a final council. The mood is cautiously optimistic. They have supplies for the Rome voyage with margin to spare. They have 694 knights fit for duty. They have favorable weather forecasts from every sailor who's looked at the sky.

March 5, 1434
Barcelona Harbor, Dawn

The fleet rides at anchor in the gray pre-dawn light: the Princesa Catalina with her red-and-gold paint gleaming, three Castilian carracks in her wake, eight Genoese transports loaded with knights and horses and all the apparatus of war.

The harbor is crowded despite the early hour. Word has spread through Barcelona that the Castilian king sails for Constantinople, and the citizens have come to watch history depart. Fishermen pause at their nets. Merchants stand on warehouse roofs. The bells of Santa María del Mar begin to toll.

Queen María stands on the royal quay with her household, wrapped against the morning chill. Beside her, little Catalina—bundled in so many layers she can barely move—watches the ships with enormous eyes.

Lucia waits at the gangplank of the Princesa Catalina, Fernando in her arms, the Portuguese and Italian ladies clustered behind her. The queen's chambers aboard have been prepared. The nursery secured against rough seas.

Commander Mendoza approaches across the cobblestones, his boots ringing in the early quiet. Behind him, the last boats ferry knights from the shore camps to the waiting transports.

"Majestad," he says, stopping at a respectful distance. "The fleet awaits your command. All vessels report ready. The tide turns within the hour."

The wind stirs the crusade banner overhead—white cloth, red cross, snapping in the morning breeze.

María steps forward. Her eyes are bright, though whether from the cold or something else is hard to say.

"Brother," she says quietly. "God keep you. And... come back."

María steps forward, her breath misting in the morning air. She looks at you for a long moment, this sister you've only begun to know again these past weeks.

She doesn't embrace you. That's not her way—not yet, perhaps not ever. But she reaches out and touches your arm, briefly, the gesture of a woman who has forgotten how to show affection and is slowly remembering.

"Don't die in some foreign sea," she says. Her voice is quiet, meant only for you. "I've only just found my brother again. It would be... inconvenient to lose him."

Behind her, her ladies wait at a respectful distance. The Bishop of Barcelona stands ready to offer a final blessing. The crowd watches in hushed anticipation.

María glances toward the Princesa Catalina, where Lucia waits at the rail with Catalina in her arms. The toddler is waving—at the seagulls, at the crowd, at everything and nothing.

"Take care of them," María adds. Then, softer: "Take care of yourself."

She steps back, her face composing itself into the mask of the Regent of Aragón.

You board the flagship as the bells of Barcelona toll the hour.

Catalina shrieks with delight as you appear on deck, squirming in Lucia's arms until she's set down to toddle toward you on unsteady sea-legs. "Papá! Boat goes NOW?"

Lucia watches you with quiet eyes. She knows what this departure means—Rome, Naples, Constantinople. Months of uncertain seas and uncertain politics. But she says nothing, only takes your hand briefly as you reach her side.

The gangplank is drawn up. The anchor chains rattle and groan. Captain Sotomayor bellows orders, and sailors scramble through the rigging.

The Princesa Catalina begins to move.

From the quay, you can see María standing motionless, one hand raised in farewell. The crowd cheers. The bells continue their toll. Barcelona slides slowly past—the Gothic spires, the crowded harbor, the city that has hosted you these long weeks.

And then open water.

The Mediterranean stretches before you, gray-green in the morning light. Somewhere beyond that horizon lies Rome. And beyond Rome, Constantinople.

I stand with Catalina and watch over the bow to the sea.


Wonderful isn't is love? The open sea. It feels a bit like flying right?

The wind catches your cloak as you lift Catalina to the rail, one arm wrapped securely around her. The Princesa Catalina cuts through the morning swell, her bow rising and falling in steady rhythm. Spray mists the air. Behind you, the coast of Catalonia is already fading to a dark line on the horizon.

Catalina grips the rail with both small hands, her eyes wide. For once, she is silent—truly silent—taking in the vastness of it. The endless gray-green water. The wheeling gulls. The way the horizon curves away into forever.

"Flying," she repeats slowly, testing the word. She looks up at you, then back at the sea.

A wave breaks against the bow, sending spray arcing upward. Catalina gasps, then laughs—that bright, startled laugh of a child discovering something wonderful.

"More!" she demands. "Boat do again!"

The ship obliges, cresting another swell. More spray. More delighted shrieking.

Then she falls quiet again, watching the water with unusual intensity for a two-year-old. The wind tugs at her hair, escaped from beneath her hood.

"Papá," she says finally, her voice thoughtful. "Where water ends?"

She points toward the horizon, where sea and sky blur into a single gray line.

"Catalina want to see."
Has Catalina found her own room? And is it cosy and warm? A nice place for Catalina to sleep?

Catalina considers this question with the grave seriousness she brings to all important matters.

"Catalina room is small," she announces, holding her hands close together to demonstrate. "But warm. Has..." She pauses, searching for the word. "Has curtains. Red ones. And Catalina's bed has—" She makes a rocking motion with her hands. "Moves. Like this."

She seems uncertain whether this is good or bad.

"Lucia-mama says Catalina sleep good when boat moves. Like..." She frowns, then mimes rocking a baby. "Like baby."

This comparison clearly offends her dignity. She is not a baby. She is Catalina.

"Catalina room is next to Papá room," she adds, brightening. "Catalina can hear Papá. If Catalina calls, Papá comes. Yes?"

She looks up at you, and for a moment the imperious little princess is just a small girl on a very big ocean, far from everything familiar.

The deck rises and falls beneath you. A sailor calls out overhead, adjusting the rigging. The Princesa Catalina sails on, carrying her namesake toward Rome.

"Papá stays close," Catalina says. It's not quite a question, not quite a command. Somewhere in between.
Yes, Papa stays close. But Catalina should also be careful by herself. Look at the wild sea? It's very cold water. Make sure you never fall down ok?

Catalina is about 2 years old (born January 28, 1432, and it's now March 1434). She's described as brilliant, commanding, beautiful, with an angel's voice - but also notably indifferent to faith (a detail that's been established but not yet revealed to Juan in full). She's imperious and confident.

Catalina looks down at the churning water below the bow. The sea is dark here, deep Mediterranean blue-black, and the white foam where the hull cuts through looks almost alive. The cold spray has already reddened her cheeks.

She studies the water for a long moment with that unsettling focus she sometimes has—the look of a child thinking thoughts too large for her years.

"Water is angry," she observes. Not frightened. Assessing.

Then she looks back up at you, and her small jaw sets in a way that reminds you, suddenly and painfully, of Isabel. That same stubborn certainty.

"Catalina never falls," she declares. "Catalina is careful."

She grips the rail tighter, demonstrating.

"But..." She hesitates. Her eyes drift back to the sea. "If Catalina did fall. Papá would catch Catalina. Yes?"

"Papá catches Catalina," she repeats, more firmly this time. Deciding it rather than asking it. "Always. Because Papá is strong."

She pats your arm with one small hand, as if reassuring you of your own capabilities.

She raises her arms to be carried, the sea and its dangers already forgotten, replaced by more pressing concerns.

You carry Catalina down the steep steps into the ship's belly, one hand on the rail as the deck shifts beneath you. The light dims—only lanterns here, swaying with the ship's motion, casting dancing shadows on the timber walls.

Catalina watches everything with wide eyes. The cramped passages. The low ceilings that even she might bump her head on in a few years. The smell of salt and tar and something cooking.

The ship's galley is a cramped space near the stern, built around a brick-lined hearth with a heavy iron grate designed to contain fire even in rough seas. The cook—a weathered Castilian named Pascual, missing two fingers on his left hand—looks up from a pot of something that smells of onions and salted fish.

"Majestad," he says, startled, nearly dropping his ladle. He bows as best he can in the confined space.

"The princess is cold," you explain. "She was hoping for hot milk with honey."

Pascual's face falls. "Milk, Majesty... we've no goats aboard. No cows." He thinks for a moment. "I have honey, though. Good Catalan honey. And..."

He rummages through his stores.

"Warm wine, watered down? With honey and a bit of cinnamon? The ladies sometimes take it so, when the chill gets in." He glances at Catalina uncertainly. "Very much watered, for the little one. More honey than wine, really."

Catalina perks up at the word honey.

"Or there's broth," Pascual offers. "Good fish broth, hot from the pot. Warms the belly."
Is Catalina thirsty or hungry?

Catalina considers this question with the gravity it deserves. She looks at the pot of broth, then at the honey pot Pascual has produced, then back at you.

"Both," she declares.

Then, sensing this might not be the answer you were looking for, she amends: "Catalina is... thirsty. But also belly is..." She pats her stomach. "Empty. Boat makes belly empty."

She eyes the honey pot again.

"Honey," she concludes firmly. "Honey fixes both."

Pascual suppresses a smile, busying himself with his ladle.

"First, the wine," you tell Catalina as the cook pours a small measure of red into a copper pot. "See? From the barrel."

"That's right. But wine is too strong for little princesses. So we add water." Pascual pours from a jug—three parts water to one part wine, perhaps more. The deep red fades to something pale and harmless.

"Now it's pink," Catalina announces, delighted by this transformation.

Pascual sets the pot on the iron grate over the coals. You crouch down so Catalina can see properly, keeping her at a safe distance from the heat.

Catalina watches the faint wisps rising from the liquid with fierce concentration.

"Honey comes from bees," you tell her. "They make it from flowers."

"And last—" Pascual produces a stick of something brown and wrinkled, "—cinnamon. From far away. Smell."

He holds it where Catalina can sniff. Her nose wrinkles, then her eyes widen.

Cagliari is a city accustomed to ships in distress. The Sardinian port has sheltered storm-battered fleets for centuries, and its people know the rhythms of maritime disaster: the counting of the living, the recovery of the dead, the grim business of salvage.

The Cathedral of Santa Maria di Castello cannot hold everyone. Knights crowd the nave, spill out into the square, line the streets. The Bishop of Cagliari—hastily summoned—presides over a Mass for the dead that lasts three hours.

One hundred and forty-two names are read aloud.

Heads bow. Lips move in private prayer. The moment stretches.

And then it ends.

The men lift their heads. They shift. They wait for what comes next.

But there is no fire in their eyes. No surge of renewed purpose. No spontaneous hymn rising from the crowd. They heard you. They respected the gesture. They observed the silence with genuine grief.

And now they are waiting to be dismissed.

Commander Mendoza glances at you—a question in his eyes. Is that all? He was hoping for more. They all were, perhaps. Or perhaps they are simply too hollowed out by loss to feel anything but exhaustion.

The knights disperse slowly, quietly. Small groups form—men from the same Order, men who lost friends together, men who simply don't want to be alone. They speak in low voices. Some embrace. A few weep.

But no one approaches you with renewed oaths. No one speaks of Constantinople with eagerness. No one seems transformed.

They will sail to Rome because you command it. They will follow orders because they are knights, because they swore oaths, because there is nothing else to do now. The dead are buried. The living must continue.

It is enough.

It has to be enough.

Commander Mendoza finds you afterward, as the square empties.

"The men will be ready to sail when you give the order, Majesty," he says. His voice is careful, neutral. "The Madonna del Mare needs another three days of repairs. The other ships are seaworthy."

He pauses.

"Do we wait for the full repairs? Or sail with what we have and let her follow?"

March 15, 1434
Cagliari Harbor, Dawn

The fleet weighs anchor under skies of pale gold.

There is no fanfare this time. No cheering crowds, no bells. Just ten ships slipping out of harbor in tight formation, their crews silent, their knights subdued. The grave in the cathedral cemetery is still fresh. The memory of the San Giovanni rolling over in the harbor mouth will not fade for years.

But the sea that greets them is not the sea that tried to kill them.

The Mediterranean lies flat and gleaming, barely a ripple marring its surface. The wind comes from the southwest—steady, warm, impossibly gentle after the mistral's fury. Captain Sotomayor checks and rechecks his instruments, as if suspecting a trick.

"I've never seen conditions like this in March," he murmurs. "Not in thirty years."

By noon, Sardinia has faded to a smudge on the horizon. By evening, the fleet has covered more distance than anyone expected.

March 16, 1434
Open Water

The second day dawns clear and mild.

Something begins to shift in the men. It starts small—a knight making a joke at breakfast, another laughing instead of staring at his hands. The oppressive silence that has hung over the expedition since Cagliari starts to crack.

In the afternoon, a cry goes up from the Santa Cruz: dolphins.

A pod of perhaps thirty, their grey backs arcing through the water, has taken up position alongside the Princesa Catalina. They ride the bow wave, leaping and diving, as if playing a game with the flagship.

Knights crowd the rails to watch. Catalina has to be held back from climbing over the side to touch them.

"Papá, fish-horses!" she shrieks, pointing. "Fish-horses are dancing!"

The dolphins stay with the fleet for hours. When they finally peel away toward open water, the men watch them go in silence—but it is a different silence than before. Wondering, not grieving.

That night, around the cookfires and in the cramped holds, men begin to speak of the dead not with hollow anguish but with something warmer. Stories emerge. Rodrigo from Santiago, who once drank a Genoese captain under the table. Old Martín of Calatrava, who could shoe a horse faster than any smith in Toledo. The quiet Alcántara sergeant whose name no one could pronounce, who prayed three times daily and never complained about anything.

The dead are remembered. And in the remembering, they become something other than weights to carry.

March 17, 1434
The Tyrrhenian Sea

The third day brings the Italian coast.

It appears at dawn—a dark line on the eastern horizon, growing slowly, resolving into hills and cliffs and the pale shapes of coastal villages. The fleet adjusts course northward, following the shoreline toward the Tiber's mouth.

The weather holds. The wind holds. The sea remains impossibly calm.

Commander Mendoza finds a moment between duties to stand at the rail, watching Italy grow closer. His face is still lined with grief—that will take months to fade, perhaps years—but something else is there now. Resolution. Purpose.

"Perhaps God took His price at the start," he says to no one in particular. "Perhaps the rest of the voyage is paid for."

It is not theology. It is the hope of a man who needs to believe that the 142 dead bought something with their lives.

March 18, 1434
Approaching Ostia

Three and a half days out of Cagliari. Exceptional time.

The fleet approaches the mouth of the Tiber in formation—battered, reduced, but together. The ten remaining ships fly their colors: the red and gold of Castile, the white crusade banner, the crosses of the three Military Orders.

And then, from the deck of the Princesa Catalina, someone begins to sing.

The voice is rough, untrained—a common knight, not a chorister. But the words are unmistakable:

Salve Regina, Mater misericordiae...

Another voice joins. Then another. The hymn spreads from ship to ship, carried across the water, swelling until six hundred voices rise together:

Vita, dulcedo, et spes nostra, salve...

The knights gather on deck, facing the approaching shore, singing to the land that holds Rome. Singing for the dead. Singing for themselves. Singing because they survived, because they are still here, because the sea gave them back when it could have taken everything.

Ad te clamamus, exsules filii Hevae...

Lucia appears at the rail beside you, Catalina in her arms. The child is quiet for once, watching the distant shore with wide eyes. Lucia's hand finds yours.

The song continues, echoing across the water, as the fleet enters the Tiber's mouth and Rome rises before you.

O clemens, O pia, O dulcis Virgo Maria.

The Harbor at Ostia
Late Afternoon

The harbor is crowded with boats—fishing vessels, merchant ships, river barges. But they have cleared a space for you. Word has traveled ahead.

As the Princesa Catalina approaches the dock, you see them: crowds lining the waterfront. Roman citizens, clergy, officials in formal robes. A delegation in papal colors waits at the foot of the main pier.

And everywhere, the sign of the cross. Men crossing themselves as the crusade banner passes. Women holding up children to see. Old men kneeling on the stones.

They have heard about the storm. They have heard that the King of Castile lost a hundred men and came on anyway. They have heard that God's wind brought him to Rome in three days.

The gangplank is lowered.

Rome awaits.
